posts.name: segev
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone! At the moment, I’m making a cascade elevator for our robot. During the course of construction, I’ve run into an issue. When I built the cascade elevator, the second stage ascendance slides without a hitch. However, the moment I press one side of the second stage, it “breaks”. The cylinder seems to lack integrity in the middle and thus turns unstable. It feels like the top and bottom of the stage are somewhat stable and rigid, and the problem is in the middle of the first stage.

Has anyone faced something similar with their cascade elevator construction? If yes, any ideas on how I can make further supports on second stage to solve this issue? This could be an issue of alignment or material strength in the cylinder’s middle, but I just do not know where to start exactly.

Thanks in advance!!

Screenshot 2025-01-22 172750 552×713 64.8 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-22 172750 552×713 64.8 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-22 172750 552×713 64.8 KB

posts.name: Justin Foss
posts.cooked: @se.sa can you provide a photo of your current setup or access to your CAD, it will be easier for people to help if they have a better understanding of your current design

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked:
I think it might be from the small distance between the rollers due to the short height of the second stage, causing it to bind when an uneven load is placed in the second stage.

What is the center to center distance between these rollers? 95f60fd62a13b7b09fbbde1ebd2eb0534090b19b~2 552×713 66.3 KB

95f60fd62a13b7b09fbbde1ebd2eb0534090b19b~2 552×713 66.3 KB

95f60fd62a13b7b09fbbde1ebd2eb0534090b19b~2 552×713 66.3 KB

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: segev
posts.cooked: From centre to centre its 35mm. The size of the second stage is 92mm by 568mm.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: With a carriage this wide and this little overlap this elevator will need to drive the carriage with rigging on each side of the elevator, not with rigging in the middle.

posts.name: segev
posts.cooked:
To move the second stage the elevator up and down we thought of using a timing belt. We were wondering if having two belts from the side will also help to prevent this problem, unlike the the cad design we have at the moment.

Screenshot 2025-01-22 175630 697×787 129 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-22 175630 697×787 129 KB

Screenshot 2025-01-22 175630 697×787 129 KB

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
It will definitely help, as long as you can individually tension each side to fine tune it.

You said the carriage is ~550 mm wide, yes?

See if you can get the attachment points approx 50 mm from each side of the carriage respectively, idea is to get them close to the bearings. Somewhere in this ballpark.

That would help a lot.

posts.name: segev
posts.cooked: If we just used two timing belts that are the same size and are the correct size / distance wouldn’t it be enough? Since the belt is held tight and are held on a bar, so one part of the belt wont move. Therefor, as long we assemble the second stage correctly with the belts, the stage wont have the ability to be pushed in those direction.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
You will want some level of adjustment.

The method you are using now with the clamping plates should work in this regard.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I agree with the comments; this is not going to work right unless you drive both ends of the second stage slider.  Its just too small an aspect ratio to self-align!  You will need to plan in both tensioning AND angular adjustment.
